review.title: Authorship Attribution Based on Life-Like Network Automata
review.abstract: The authorship attribution is a problem of considerable practical and technical interest. Several methods have been designed to infer the authorship of disputed documents in multiple contexts. While traditional statistical methods based solely on word counts and related measurements have provided a simple, yet effective solution in particular cases; they are prone to manipulation. Recently, texts have been successfully modeled as networks, where words are represented by nodes linked according to textual similarity measurements. Such models are useful to identify informative topological patterns for the authorship recognition task. However, there is no consensus on which measurements should be used. Thus, we proposed a novel method to characterize text networks, by considering both topological and dynamical aspects of networks. Using concepts and methods from cellular automata theory, we devised a strategy to grasp informative spatio-temporal patterns from this model. Our experiments revealed an outperformance over traditional analysis relying only on topological measurements. Remarkably, we have found a dependence of pre-processing steps (such as the lemmatization) on the obtained results, a feature that has mostly been disregarded in related works. The optimized results obtained here pave the way for a better characterization of textual networks.

sections.text: Authorship assignment is a problem of considerable practical and technical interest. Several methods have been developed to infer the authorship of disputed documents in multiple contexts. While traditional statistical methods based solely on word count and related measurements offered a simple but effective solution in certain cases, they are prone to manipulation. Therefore, texts have been successfully modelled as networks in which words are represented by nodes linked together after text similarity measurements. Such models are useful for identifying informative patterns for the task of authoring. However, there is no consensus on which measurements should be used. Therefore, we proposed a new method for characterizing text networks, taking into account both topological and dynamic aspects of networks. Using concepts and methods from cellular automation theory, we developed a strategy to capture informative spatio-temporal patterns from this model.

sections.heading: CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this paper, we have addressed the problem of author attribution, which is a task of practical relevance in many contexts of information science. We have specifically investigated the impact of textual organization on the discriminability of documents written by different authors. To do this, we have used the well-known network framework that reveals its potential in related applications. Unlike the traditional approach, which is based only on the topological characteristics of networks, we have proposed a methodology for collecting further information relating to certain styles of authors. To this end, we have represented networks that provide texts with a dynamic based on life-like rules.
